div.head: TO THE READER
div.p:
IT was this Con≈øideration that gave birth to the Adventure of the Renowned Columbus, That the parts of the Earth and Sea di≈øcovered, made up but half the Globe: And he could not imagine that the Wi≈ødom of the Creator would de≈øign ≈øo va≈øt a Compa≈øs as mu≈øt make up the other part only for Fi≈øhes to inhabit ∆≤pon this principle of rea≈øon, which carried with it a great probability of Succe≈øs, He fir≈øt ≈øolicited Henry the Seventh of England; but being denied there, he made his Addre≈øs to Ferdinand King of Ca≈øtile, who by the per≈øwa≈øion of Elizabeth his Queen ≈øet out a ≈ømall number of Ships, which after ≈øome Months ≈øailing We≈øtward (not without the murmurings and de≈øpair of the Seamen) at length di≈øcovered an unknown, yet habitable World.
This Succe≈øs of Columbus ≈øounded by the Trump of Fame awakened the ≈øloathful and incredulous World, who before would believe nothing po≈ø≈øible but what their eyes could behold, or their outward ≈øen≈øes fathom: The World thus awakened, and having wiped their eyes with the Gold of COLUMBINA, ≈øaw more clearly their former Errors: Now the Golden-Age returns again Gold is exchanged for trifles, ≈øuch as Knives, Hatchets, &c. which were valued at ≈øix times their weight in Gold; and Pearls, and Diamonds bear but an equal value with gla≈øs: But this la≈øted not long; for immediately ≈øuch multitudes of Ships lanched out with expectations of gain, that they ≈øoon exhau≈øted the di≈øcovered Mines, and reduced it almo≈øt to an equal value with that of Europe. Ferme omnes ≈øceleratus amor nunc urget Habendi.

What crouding to the We≈øt! with what cunning do they catch and enclo≈øe the Wind, from what corner ≈øo-ever it comes, and make it ≈øerve their purpo≈øe! What prying is now into the private rece≈ø≈øes of Thetis! Never was more rapes committed upon the Virgin-Rivers than in this age.

Several Di≈øcoveries was made, ≈øo that none lo≈øt their labour; and ≈øince that time many places have been di≈øcovered, and yet there remains above a fourth part undi≈øcovered; this gave me encouragement to take upon me this Adventure, though not without great trouble and care, ≈øuch as the want of many Nece≈ø≈øaries for my ≈øelf and Seamen, which were much afflicted with a de≈øperate Sickne≈øs, that did deprive me of mo≈øt of them; but I accidentally met with a ve≈ø≈øel that lent me ≈øome of her men, which gave me greater encouragement to proceed in my Di≈øcovery, which Divine Providence did ble≈øs with ≈øucce≈øs; for in four days after I came out of Fretum le Mair, I di≈øcovered the Land, which in the following Treati≈øe I give you a relation of.

I do not doubt but this Di≈øcovery will be beneficial to Europe many ways; fir≈øt as it may encourage ≈øeveral others to proceed in the like Adventures which may happily find out other Lands, and likewi≈øe the≈øe particular I≈ølands may be beneficial, they being very fruitful, not over-peopled; abounding with many rich Mines, be≈øides Pearls and precious Stones, with many other rich Commodities. The Inhabitants are a people very humane, witty, and intelligent, ready to receive any In≈øtructions, and may be ea≈øily brought to Traffick.
If you accept of this my pains in the Di≈øcovery and Relation, I ≈øhall think my time well be≈øtowed, and may po≈ø≈øibly by your acceptance be encouraged to make a ≈øecond Adventure, in the mean time

div.head: A De≈øcription OF THE ISLANDS OF BENGANGA and COMA.
SECT. I. A Voyage from Am≈øterdam into the Southern Sea.
div.p:
ON January 1, 1669, We ≈øet Sail from Am≈øterdam in the Ve≈ø≈øel called the Flying-Faulcon: The De≈øign of our Voyage being wholly Di≈øcovery. We made way to the Southern Sea; the twentieth of Augu≈øt following we came to the Streights of Magalan; and on the twenty ≈øixth we had a ≈øight of Terra del Fuega, by
which we Coa≈øted three or four days, and then left; pa≈ø≈øing through Fretum le Mair into the Main-Ocean called Mare del Zur: on the ≈øixth of September following we took an Ob≈øervation, and found our ≈øelves in the Latitude of fifty degrees fourteen minutes. The Wind at Ea≈øt and by South; we ≈øailed directly before the Wind; and on the tenth of September in the Evening we di≈øcovered Fire, an a≈ø≈øured te≈øtimony of ≈øome Land: but early in the Morning we were better c ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ firmed in our belief, being in ≈øight of the very Land, and within a mile or thereabouts of it: we Coa≈øted along ≈øeveral days, and could ≈øpy no Towns or Hou≈øes, but di≈øcovered many good Ports and Promontaries. On the thirtieth of September we di≈øcovered another piece of Land ≈øeparate from this by a River or Fretum, a League and half in breadth. We ≈øtill continued our Di≈øcovery by Coa≈øting along this Land likewi≈øe. About the Eighteenth of November following we came to the other end of the Fretum before di≈øcovered, by which we knew it to be an I≈øland that we had di≈øcovered, and by computation Judg both the I≈ølands to be in Compa≈øs about three hundred Leagues: we ventured into this Fretum, and at our entrance, I gave it the name of Fretum del Schooten. As we pa≈ø≈øed along we could di≈øcover on the Banks, People of an extraordinary ≈øize, and hairy: Having ≈øailed about ≈øeven Leagues we di≈øcovered a River running Ea≈øtward up into the fir≈øt I≈øland; into this River we ventured, and having ≈øailed about a mile, we di≈øcovered a Town (as we ≈øuppo≈øed by the great quantity of Smoak that a≈øcended from thence); at
length drawing nearer to it we e≈øpied Hou≈øes, or rather Hills as they ≈øeemed to us by their Gra≈øs-Coverings; before this Town we ca≈øt Anchor, and made an Ob≈øervation, and found our ≈øelves in the Latitude of fifty Degrees thirteen Minutes, South; and the Longitude Two hundred ≈øeventy five Degrees thirty Minutes. We had not rid at Anchor above three hours before we could e≈øpy a Canoo coming over to us from the Town; the rea≈øon of which we could not well apprehend; at length drawing near to us, we e≈øpied in it an European, as his Complexion and Habit did ≈øhow; he had in his hand a ≈øhattered torn Jack-flag, in which we might di≈øcover ≈øomething of the Portugal Arms: Being come to the Ship-≈øide, he ≈øaluted us with the≈øe words, Dios vos guarda hermanos; which in the Portugue≈øe language ≈øignifies, God ≈øave you my Brethren: I then returned his Salutation in his own language, ≈øaying, Sea bien veni do Hermano. Welcome Brother; and invited him into the Ship: which Invitation he willingly accepted, and came into the Ship; our Seamen would have taken the men in the Canoo into the Ship, but he would not ≈øuffer them, telling us they were Slaves, and ought not to be ≈øo much Countenanced: We took this Portugue≈øe into the great Cabin, and gave him the be≈øt Entertainment our Ship could afford; after three or four hours ≈øtay in our Ship, he took his leave, and gave us an Invitation to his Hou≈øe, which he told us was in that Town we ≈øaw; and promi≈øed likewi≈øe to ≈øend Canoo's for the whole Ship's Company, which he accordingly performed in the Morning following.

The Natives that Rowed in the Canoo's were all hairy, having no other Cloathing than what Nature had furni≈øhed them withall; and the lea≈øt of them by computation above Eleven foot high; by the≈øe Gygantick men, we were ≈øafely conducted to the Town, which con≈øi≈øted of about a thou≈øand Hou≈øes, built of Timber, and covered over the top with Boughs of Trees wreathed together; and over them were placed very curiou≈øly Gr ‚Ä¢ en≈øads, which make their Hou≈øes look like ≈øo many Hills covered with Gra≈øs.

At length we were Conducted to this Portugue≈øe Hou≈øe, who it ≈øeems was Governour of this Town, and Cacique, or King of that part of the Country: His Hou≈øe was built after the ≈øame manner with the re≈øt, bur much bigger.

At the Entrance to his Hou≈øe he received us with a great deal of Expre≈ø≈øions of Joy, and conducted us into a very fair Room, where we were plentifully entertained with roa≈øted Veni≈øon, and Wine in abundance
Having pretty well ≈øatisfied our ≈øelves, he di≈øcour≈øed with us concerning our Adventures, and related to us the manner of his Adventures, ≈øince his coming from Lisbon, after this manner.

div.head: SECT. II. The Adventures of Va≈øques de Pagna, from the year 1646, to November 1670; as it was related by him≈øelf to Henry Schooten.
div.p:
I Va≈øques de Pagna ≈øet ≈øail from Lisbon in the year One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty-≈øix, upon the ≈øame account that you did from Am≈øterdam, and by accident made this I≈øland: being curious in the Di≈øcovery, I fir≈øt Coa≈øted about the two I≈ølands, and then put into the Fretum, that parts the two I≈ølands; and ob≈øerving this River that runs up into the Country, I ventured into it; re≈øolving to venture ≈øo far till I could ≈øee either Hou≈øes or Inhabitants; but by the neglect of my Mate, not being careful enough in ≈øounding the Channel, my Ship unfortunately ≈øtruck upon a Sand, and ≈øplit in a very ≈øhort time, giving us little ≈øpace to ≈øhift for our lives; in this ≈øtreight every Man endeavouring to ≈øave him≈øelf, my ≈øelf with two more got ≈øafe to the Shore; but of the re≈øt of our Company I never could hear of ≈øince, and therefore conclude they were all drowned. We ≈øought about for ≈øhelter from the Cold and Rain, it being about the time of the Winter-Sol≈øtice, at which time it is rather Colder than it is with you in Europe.
At length we found a large hollow Tree, into which we entred, and ≈ølept for that night.

The next Morning as ≈øoon as we could ≈øee, we went to the Water-≈øide to ≈øee whether any thing was driven a ≈øhore, or floated near to Land; when we came there we e≈øpied ≈øeveral pieces of our Ship floating about; and walking along by the ≈øhore we found a Barrel of Bisket, and near to that our Jack-Flag, both which we took up and went away very joyfully towards our Arbour, where we ≈øecured them, and gave thanks to God for his great mercy in making ≈øuch Provi≈øion for us: Upon this Bisket we lived about three Months, and ≈øpent our time in Prayers, and walking the Grounds near to the Tree, retreating upon the lea≈øt noi≈øe to our Harbour: In the ≈øecond Month one of my Companions fell ≈øick and died, and at three Months end my other Companion.

Now was I left in a mi≈øerable Condition, my Company dead, and my Victuals almo≈øt ≈øpent; but however I comforted my ≈øelf with the≈øe thoughts, that the ≈øame God that hitherto had ≈øo plentifully provided for me, would ≈øtill take care of me; I now re≈øolved to travel up farther into the Country, and if there were any Inhabitants (for as yet I had ≈øeen none) to commit my ≈øelf to their mercy; being thus re≈øolved, I thought to leave ≈øome Memorial behind me, that if it ≈øhould happen that any European ≈øhould light upon this place, they might know what Adventure I had made; I therefore took the Jack-Flag, and with a black-lead Pencil writ the≈øe Words as plain as I could, Va≈øques de Pagna of Lisbon was here; and then ≈øecured it in a convenient place in the Tree,
where it might be ≈øecure from the injuries of weather. Then I took the remainder of the Bisket, and de≈øired God to pro≈øper my Journey, and travelled into the Country.

In two days travel I di≈øcovered hairy people, ≈øuch as you ≈øee; at fir≈øt I was ≈øomething fearful of them, but my fear was ≈øoon taken away, for I found them to be more fearful of me, admiring at my Clothes and Complexion; and were ready to adore me. Walking a little further, I could e≈øpy, as it were, a grove of Hills which were their Hou≈øes, who≈øe plea≈øant Verdure was very delightful; being come near to the Town, I was ≈øurrounded with hundreds of the≈øe Hairy-people, admiring me, and making offers to adore me, ≈øuppo≈øing I was a god; but I did what I could to hinder them. At length it came to the King's ear, who came him≈øelf with ≈øeveral Prie≈øts to vi≈øit me, and made ≈øigns to me to let them know what I was; fir≈øt lifting up their eyes to Heaven, and then pointing to me, and then to the Heavens again; but I let them under≈øtand by the like ≈øigns, that I did not come immediately from Heaven, but hoped to go thither; and this I did by fir≈øt pointing to the Earth from whence I came, and to the Heavens whether I hoped to go. With which they were well ≈øatisfied, and conducted me to the Caciques Hou≈øe (for ≈øo they call their Kings): The Cacique telling his Prie≈øt (as I have been ≈øince informed by his Daughter my Wife) that I was of Coele≈øtial Extract, and fit for no Company but the Gods and Kings. At this Palace I fared very well; and having very ≈ømall hopes of returning to my Country, or ≈øeeing any of Europe,
I thought it my be≈øt way to a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelf of a Being among≈øt them, and this I did by ingratiating my ≈øelf with the Cacique's Daughter, whom I found very ready to receive any kindne≈øs from me; her Father likewi≈øe ca≈øting a plea≈øant a≈øpect on both, did give me encouragement to make ≈øome offers of Amours, which was kindly received, and we in a ≈øhort time married according to the Cu≈øtom of the Countrey; of which with their other Rites and Cu≈øtoms, I ≈øhall give you a full account hereafter. Being married, he gave me Two hundred Slaves, and bid me chu≈øe out a place in the I≈øland to inhabit, and build a Town that might be called by my Name.

Having taken my leave, I with my Wife and Slaves with ≈øtore of all ≈øorts of Provi≈øion, came towards this place, which I the rather made choice of, becau≈øe it was the place I formerly had taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of; likewi≈øe hoping, that being near to this River, ≈øome European might at ≈øome time or other happen to ≈øail into it, as I had done.

div.head: SECT. III. A Continuation of the Relation, with the manner of the Portugue≈øe treating us.
div.p:
HAving given us this relation of his Adventure, he carried us and ≈øhewed us the hollow Tree they fir≈øt lodged in, which ≈øtands at the entrance to his Hou≈øe, painted with a ≈øort of red Paint, like to our Oker, but much brighter colour; with which Commodity that part of the Countrey doth much abound: Then he carried us, and ≈øhewed us the places where he formerly had buried his Companions, over who≈øe Bodies he had cau≈øed to be erected Pyramids, covered with Mo≈øs, and curiou≈øly checkered with Boughs of Trees woven together cro≈øswi≈øe. Having done this, he carried us into a ≈øtately large Room, who≈øe Wall in≈øtead of Tapi≈øtry was bedeck't with Flowers and growing Mo≈øs, and checker'd with Boughs after the manner of the Pyramids (before mentioned); on the upper end of which, on a Seat or Bank, ≈øate his Lady with Four Children; his Lady was near Twelve Foot high, his Elde≈øt Son, about Twenty years of age, was more than Twelve foot; his Second Son about Sixteen years of age, above Ten foot; his two Daughters
younger, one was Nine foot, and the other Seven foot in heighth. But that which was mo≈øt remarkable, was, that his Second Son and Elde≈øt Daughter were ≈ømooth as we are, and yet retained the Nature of the Countrey as to height.

Being pretty well ≈øatisfied with our entertainment and diver≈øions, we de≈øired his leave to return to our ≈øhip, but he would not grant it, telling us that we ≈øhould lye there that night; and then conducted us into another large Room, wherein was Hammocks provided for us to lye upon; here he treated us again with two or three Movyles of Wine, (which Movyle contained about a Gallon); having drank up our Wine, he bid us good-night, and left us to our repo≈øe.

Next morning as ≈øoon as Sun was up, he came to us, and asked us how we ≈ølept, and called for a Movyle of Wine for our Morning's-draught, and cau≈øed likewi≈øe ≈øome Veni≈øon to be brought to us, with which having broke our fa≈øt, he carried us to ≈øee his Town, and the Church which he had built. He told us, at his fir≈øt coming to this place he was both King and Prie≈øt. And that he had converted his Wife, and had baptized her and all the inhabitants of the place, being all as his dome≈øtick Servants; but ≈øince, the people encrea≈øing, he had con≈øtituted other Prie≈øts. After this di≈øcour≈øe in the Church, we returned to his Hou≈øe, where he gave order for a Dinner to be provided for us, in the mean time he entertained us with a farther relation of the Government and Cu≈øtoms of this I≈øland in the≈øe words following.

div.head: SECT. IV. Of the Government, Religion, and Cu≈øtoms of the Inhabitants: With the nature of the Soil, and the ≈øeveral Commodities of the I≈øland Benganga.
div.p: THis I≈øland wherein you are, is called by the Natives Benganga, Governed this thou≈øand years by the Family of Gangois, of which Family my Father-in-law is; who is called by the name of Conumbro Bengangois: his chief ≈øeat is Cubugnello, the Town where I was Entertained and Married. He is the Ab≈øolute Monarch of the I≈øland, and hath Fourty petty Kings that live about him, that do Homage, and pay Tribute to him yearly.

They wor≈øhip in all parts of this I≈øland, except mine, the Devil, who appears to them very often in a mi≈øty cloud, uttering or mumbling out ≈øome words concerning his will; which if they do not punctually perform, ≈øome great misfortune happens, either to them or their Children ≈øoon after. They believe that they that live well here, and do no man any injury, and obey the Laws of the Cacique, they ≈øhall enjoy much happine≈øs after death, in plea≈øant fields, behind the Hills. At three times of the year they offer Sacrifices to their Dieu (as they call him) who appears in a
Cloud upon a high Mountain all the time of their Sacrificing; and the≈øe Sacrifices are ≈øometimes Goats, and ≈øometime Children.

Their manner of Marriage is in this manner: The Parents of both parties being fir≈øt agreed, the Father of the Maid brings out his Daughter to the Youngman, and they immediately upon the fir≈øt ≈øight declare to their Patents their liking or refu≈øal of each other; if they declare their liking, the Father of the Damo≈øel in the pre≈øence of one of their Fritazeers, or Prie≈øts, gives his Daughter to the Young-man, and with her gives her Dowry, which is one or more Servants, according to his ability and their former agreement; after this the Fritazeer offers a Sacrifice to the Dieu, and the Marriage is celebrated. They are here allowed to have but one Wife; and if either die, they are not permitted to marry again: Both Men and Women here are very cha≈øt and temperate in meat and drink: Their Women are not ≈øo fruitful as in Europe, it being a rare thing for one to ≈øee four Children in a Family. Theft and Murder are here ≈øeverely puni≈øhed with cruel Tortures unto death; ≈øo that a ≈øtranger may ≈øafely travel in this I≈øland without fear of harm, except it be from Bears which lurk in the Woods, with which this I≈øland is well ≈øtored.

The Commodities of this I≈øland are Saunders, Palm-trees, Konock a ≈øort of paint, Ca≈ø≈øanack a kind of Pults of which they make their bread; great plenty of Goats and Deer, Fowl of ≈øeveral ≈øorts, Fi≈øh in abundance, Otters and Beevers good ≈øtore. Here are al≈øo ≈øeveral Gold and Silver Mines, but they are not much regarded by the Inhabitants, they adorning them≈øelves
more with Pearl and Amber, with which this Country is well ≈øtored. Their Drink is Palm-Wine, which they make after this manner: They bore a hole in the tree, and put into the hole a hollow Cane, and at the end of the tap they hang a ve≈ø≈øel to catch the liquor: in an hours time if the Tree be any thing large, there will run out a gallon; this liquor is fit to drink pre≈øently, and is very plea≈øant and ≈øpiritous, intoxicating the brain, as ≈øoon as the mo≈øt generous Wine in Europe; here are ≈øeveral acres of ground yearly planted with the≈øe Trees, which ≈øerve for the u≈øe afore≈øaid.
